review: In the past I ran a multiroom Logitech Squeezebox setup, with a 4TB NAS for all my music files. However, it was confusing to operate and needed to be completely rebuilt every 4 - 6 months when the receivers lost their network connectivity. Then, along came my new Google Chromecast and I can't believe how well Google have solved this problem.The setup is one of the easiest I have ever experienced for any electronic device, EVER. Seriously, it's that well though through.After plugging it in to the HDMI port on my stereo receiver, we now send music (from Google Play), YouTube videos, Movies, etc to it from a previously retired Android tablet that is now mounted on a cabinet door in the kitchen. My wife loves how easy it is to operate and how flawlessly it always just works.Frankly, I resent the fact that this is yet another area in my life that I am handing over to Google, but you cannot deny that they have come along into this entirely new market sector and just solved it so elegantly. Fantastic device.Negatives:  1) I wish you could have multilple Chromecasts in multiple rooms and sync them.  2) I wish you could cast a browser tab from an Android device like you can with a desktop chrome browser  3) The number of services / apps that support Chromecast are currently small, but growing.For this kind of money, you really can't go wrong.
author: Jason Shapiro "Jay Shapiro"

review: I bought this so that I could stream Netflix Super HD content to my front room, to replace a PS3 I was planning to sell that was currently performing the same purpose.I connected it to my network and enabled UPnP in my router, but Netflix videos were extremely pixelated and were clearly using a low bitrate. When I used Netflix's "Example Short 23.976" diagnostic video to see what was going on, I found that my streaming speed would never get close to the 5800kbps of Super HD (that my PS3 located inches away was currently providing), and instead topped out at ~3000kbps and would not go higher.In addition, sometimes the bitrate would "lock" at an extremely low value (usually around 250kbps) and would look absolutely terrible. Sometimes tracking through a title would fix this, but not always.I contacted Google's Chromecast support, who informed me that my unit "does not seem to be defective" and suggested "moving (your) router closer to the Chromecast". Given that I was able to stream Super HD content to both my PS3 and a laptop in that location without issue, this was not going to happen. It is my belief that my Chromecast was either defective or just sucked, and given the generally positive reviews posted here and elsewhere then I can only conclude the former.I am returning the unit to Amazon for a refund.
author: Amazon Customer
